The ECHR also observed that contemporary scholarship generally concurs that the ethnic cleansing conducted by Serb forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina to displace Muslims and Croats does not constitute genocide. data.text: About 30 people have been indicted for participating in genocide or complicity in genocide during the early 1990s in Bosnia. To date, after several plea bargains and some convictions that were successfully challenged on appeal two men, Vujadin Popović and Ljubiša Beara, have been found guilty of committing genocide, Zdravko Tolimir has been found guilty of committing genocide and conspiracy to commit genocide, and two others, Radislav Krstić and Drago Nikolić, have been found guilty of aiding and abetting genocide. Three others have been found guilty of participating in genocides in Bosnia by German courts, one of whom Nikola Jorgić lost an appeal against his conviction in the European Court of Human Rights. A further eight men, former members of the Bosnian Serb security forces were found guilty of genocide by the State Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina (See List of Bosnian genocide prosecutions).

data.text: Slobodan Milošević, as the former President of Serbia and of Yugoslavia, was the most senior political figure to stand trial at the ICTY. He died on 11 March 2006 during his trial where he was accused of genocide or complicity in genocide in territories within Bosnia and Herzegovina, so no verdict was returned. In 1995, the ICTY issued a warrant for the arrest of Bosnian Serbs Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić on several charges including genocide. On 21 July 2008, Karadžić was arrested in Belgrade, and he is currently in The Hague on trial accused of genocide among other crimes. Ratko Mladić was arrested on 26 May 2011 by Serbian special police in Lazarevo, Serbia. Karadzic was convicted of ten of the eleven charges laid against him and sentenced to 40 years in prison on March 24 2016.

data.text: The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR) is a court under the auspices of the United Nations for the prosecution of offenses committed in Rwanda during the genocide which occurred there during April 1994, commencing on 6 April. The ICTR was created on 8 November 1994 by the Security Council of the United Nations in order to judge those people responsible for the acts of genocide and other serious violations of the international law performed in the territory of Rwanda, or by Rwandan citizens in nearby states, between 1 January and 31 December 1994.

Created by the UN Security Council on November 8, 1994, its mandate includes judging individuals responsible for acts of genocide and other severe breaches of international law within Rwanda or perpetrated by Rwandans in neighboring countries during that period.

data.text: There has been much debate over categorizing the situation in Darfur as genocide. The ongoing conflict in Darfur, Sudan, which started in 2003, was declared a "genocide" by United States Secretary of State Colin Powell on 9 September 2004 in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Since that time however, no other permanent member of the UN Security Council followed suit. In fact, in January 2005, an International Commission of Inquiry on Darfur, authorized by UN Security Council Resolution 1564 of 2004, issued a report to the Secretary-General stating that "the Government of the Sudan has not pursued a policy of genocide." Nevertheless, the Commission cautioned that "The conclusion that no genocidal policy has been pursued and implemented in Darfur by the Government authorities, directly or through the militias under their control, should not be taken in any way as detracting from the gravity of the crimes perpetrated in that region. International offences such as the crimes against humanity and war crimes that have been committed in Darfur may be no less serious and heinous than genocide."
data.label: human

data.text: The classification of the situation in Darfur as genocide has sparked considerable debate. The conflict in Darfur, Sudan, which began in 2003, was labeled "genocide" by then U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell on September 9, 2004, during a testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. However, since then, no other permanent member of the UN Security Council has concurred with this designation. In January 2005, an International Commission of Inquiry on Darfur—established by UN Security Council Resolution 1564 in 2004—submitted a report to the Secretary-General concluding that "the Government of Sudan did not pursue a policy of genocide." The Commission warned that recognizing no genocidal intent does not diminish the severity of crimes committed in the region. It noted that international offenses, such as crimes against humanity and war crimes, perpetrated in Darfur could be equally severe and heinous as genocide.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: The designation of events in Darfur as "genocide" has led to significant discussion. In 2003, conflict erupted in Darfur, Sudan, and on September 9, 2004, U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell labeled it "genocide" during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing. However, no other permanent UN Security Council member has since agreed with this classification. An International Commission of Inquiry on Darfur, set up by UN Security Council Resolution 1564 in 2004, reported to the Secretary-General in January 2005 that the Government of Sudan did not implement a policy of genocide. The Commission highlighted that the absence of genocidal intent does not lessen the seriousness of the region's crimes. It also pointed out that international crimes such as crimes against humanity and war crimes committed in Darfur could be just as severe and reprehensible as genocide.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: In March 2005, the Security Council formally referred the situation in Darfur to the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, taking into account the Commission report but without mentioning any specific crimes. Two permanent members of the Security Council, the United States and China, abstained from the vote on the referral resolution. As of his fourth report to the Security Council, the Prosecutor has found "reasonable grounds to believe that the individuals identified [in the UN Security Council Resolution 1593] have committed crimes against humanity and war crimes," but did not find sufficient evidence to prosecute for genocide.
data.label: human

data.text: In March 2005, the Security Council formally directed the situation in Darfur to the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, considering the Commission's findings without specifying particular offenses. The United States and China, both permanent members, abstained from voting on this referral resolution. As outlined in his fourth report to the Security Council, the Prosecutor determined there are "reasonable grounds to believe" that those identified under UN Security Council Resolution 1593 have committed crimes against humanity and war crimes; however, he found insufficient evidence to pursue charges of genocide.

data.text: In March 2005, the Security Council formally referred the situation in Darfur to the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court based on the Commission's findings, without specifying particular offenses. Both the United States and China, permanent members, abstained from voting on this referral resolution. As detailed in his fourth report to the Security Council, the Prosecutor concluded there are "reasonable grounds to believe" that individuals identified under UN Security Council Resolution 1593 have committed crimes against humanity and war crimes; however, he found insufficient evidence to pursue genocide charges.

data.text: Other authors have focused on the structural conditions leading up to genocide and the psychological and social processes that create an evolution toward genocide. Ervin Staub showed that economic deterioration and political confusion and disorganization were starting points of increasing discrimination and violence in many instances of genocides and mass killing. They lead to scapegoating a group and ideologies that identified that group as an enemy. A history of devaluation of the group that becomes the victim, past violence against the group that becomes the perpetrator leading to psychological wounds, authoritarian cultures and political systems, and the passivity of internal and external witnesses (bystanders) all contribute to the probability that the violence develops into genocide. Intense conflict between groups that is unresolved, becomes intractable and violent can also lead to genocide. The conditions that lead to genocide provide guidance to early prevention, such as humanizing a devalued group, creating ideologies that embrace all groups, and activating bystander responses. There is substantial research to indicate how this can be done, but information is only slowly transformed into action.
data.label: human

data.text: Other scholars have concentrated on the structural circumstances preceding genocide and the psychological and social dynamics that steer toward it. Ervin Staub highlighted that economic decline, along with political confusion and disarray, often initiate discrimination and violence in numerous cases of genocides and mass killings. These factors lead to the scapegoating of a group and ideologies portraying that group as an enemy. A history of devaluing the victimized group, past aggression by future perpetrators resulting in psychological trauma, authoritarian cultures and political systems, and the apathy of both internal and external onlookers (bystanders) all heighten the likelihood of escalating violence into genocide. Severe, unresolved conflicts between groups that become entrenched and violent can also culminate in genocide. The conditions leading to genocide offer insights for early prevention by humanizing marginalized groups, fostering inclusive ideologies, and encouraging bystander intervention. There is considerable research indicating how these measures can be implemented, yet the translation of this information into action progresses slowly.

data.text: Other researchers have focused on the structural factors that precede genocide and the psychological and social dynamics leading to it. Ervin Staub noted that economic downturns, coupled with political instability and chaos, often spark discrimination and violence in many instances of genocides and mass killings. These elements lead to scapegoating a group and fostering ideologies that depict this group as an enemy. A history of devaluing the victimized group, past aggression by those who will become perpetrators causing psychological trauma, authoritarian cultures and political systems, along with the indifference of both internal and external observers (bystanders), all increase the risk of escalating violence into genocide. Deep-seated, violent conflicts between groups can also evolve into genocide. The conditions preceding genocide provide insights for early prevention through humanizing marginalized groups, promoting inclusive ideologies, and encouraging bystander intervention. data.text: The emergence of resistance of bacteria to antibiotics is a common phenomenon. Emergence of resistance often reflects evolutionary processes that take place during antibiotic therapy. The antibiotic treatment may select for bacterial strains with physiologically or genetically enhanced capacity to survive high doses of antibiotics. Under certain conditions, it may result in preferential growth of resistant bacteria, while growth of susceptible bacteria is inhibited by the drug. For example, antibacterial selection for strains having previously acquired antibacterial-resistance genes was demonstrated in 1943 by the Luria–Delbrück experiment. Antibiotics such as penicillin and erythromycin, which used to have a high efficacy against many bacterial species and strains, have become less effective, due to the increased resistance of many bacterial strains.
data.label: human

data.text: The development of antibiotic resistance in bacteria is a frequently observed phenomenon. This resistance often mirrors evolutionary processes occurring during antibiotic treatment. Such treatments can favor bacterial strains with enhanced physiological or genetic abilities to withstand high doses of antibiotics. Under specific conditions, this may lead to the preferential growth of resistant bacteria while inhibiting susceptible ones through drug action. For instance, in 1943, the Luria–Delbrück experiment demonstrated antibacterial selection for strains that had previously acquired resistance genes. Antibiotics like penicillin and erythromycin, once highly effective against numerous bacterial species and strains, have diminished in efficacy due to increased resistance among many bacterial populations.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: The emergence of antibiotic resistance in bacteria is a well-documented phenomenon often reflecting evolutionary processes during treatment with antibiotics. These treatments can promote the proliferation of bacterial strains possessing enhanced physiological or genetic traits that allow them to survive high doses of antibiotics. Under certain conditions, this results in the selective growth of resistant bacteria while susceptible ones are suppressed by drug action. For example, the Luria–Delbrück experiment in 1943 illustrated antibacterial selection for strains that had already acquired resistance genes. Antibiotics such as penicillin and erythromycin, once highly effective against many bacterial species and strains, have become less efficacious due to growing resistance among various bacterial populations.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: The successful outcome of antimicrobial therapy with antibacterial compounds depends on several factors. These include host defense mechanisms, the location of infection, and the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties of the antibacterial. A bactericidal activity of antibacterials may depend on the bacterial growth phase, and it often requires ongoing metabolic activity and division of bacterial cells. These findings are based on laboratory studies, and in clinical settings have also been shown to eliminate bacterial infection. Since the activity of antibacterials depends frequently on its concentration, in vitro characterization of antibacterial activity commonly includes the determination of the minimum inhibitory concentration and minimum bactericidal concentration of an antibacterial. To predict clinical outcome, the antimicrobial activity of an antibacterial is usually combined with its pharmacokinetic profile, and several pharmacological parameters are used as markers of drug efficacy.
data.label: human

data.text: The effectiveness of antimicrobial therapy using antibacterial agents relies on multiple factors such as host defense mechanisms, infection site, and the pharmacokinetics and dynamics of the antibiotic. The bactericidal effect of these agents often depends on the bacterial growth phase and typically requires continuous metabolic activity and cell division. These insights originate from laboratory studies but have also proven to eradicate infections in clinical environments. Given that an antibacterial's action is frequently concentration-dependent, its in vitro characterization usually involves determining the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) and minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC). To forecast clinical outcomes, antimicrobial activity is assessed alongside pharmacokinetic profiles, using various pharmacological parameters as efficacy markers.

data.text: Antibacterial antibiotics are commonly classified based on their mechanism of action, chemical structure, or spectrum of activity. Most target bacterial functions or growth processes. Those that target the bacterial cell wall (penicillins and cephalosporins) or the cell membrane (polymyxins), or interfere with essential bacterial enzymes (rifamycins, lipiarmycins, quinolones, and sulfonamides) have bactericidal activities. Those that target protein synthesis (macrolides, lincosamides and tetracyclines) are usually bacteriostatic (with the exception of bactericidal aminoglycosides). Further categorization is based on their target specificity. "Narrow-spectrum" antibacterial antibiotics target specific types of bacteria, such as Gram-negative or Gram-positive bacteria, whereas broad-spectrum antibiotics affect a wide range of bacteria. Following a 40-year hiatus in discovering new classes of antibacterial compounds, four new classes of antibacterial antibiotics have been brought into clinical use in the late 2000s and early 2010s: cyclic lipopeptides (such as daptomycin), glycylcyclines (such as tigecycline), oxazolidinones (such as linezolid), and lipiarmycins (such as fidaxomicin).
data.label: human

data.text:
Antibacterial antibiotics are typically categorized by their mechanism of action, chemical structure, or spectrum of activity. They primarily target bacterial functions or growth processes. Antibiotics that affect the bacterial cell wall (like penicillins and cephalosporins) or cell membrane (such as polymyxins), or inhibit crucial bacterial enzymes (including rifamycins, lipiarmycins, quinolones, and sulfonamides) are generally bactericidal. Those that interfere with protein synthesis (such as macrolides, lincosamides, and tetracyclines) tend to be bacteriostatic, although some aminoglycosides exhibit bactericidal properties. Further classification is based on target specificity; "narrow-spectrum" antibiotics specifically target certain bacteria types like Gram-negative or Gram-positive bacteria, while broad-spectrum antibiotics act against a wide range of bacteria.

After a 40-year gap in identifying new antibacterial compound classes, four novel categories were introduced into clinical use between the late 2000s and early 2010s: cyclic lipopeptides (e.g., daptomycin), glycylcyclines (e.g., tigecycline), oxazolidinones (e.g., linezolid), and lipiarmycins (e.g., fidaxomicin).
data.label: qwen_1

data.text:
Antibacterial antibiotics are generally classified based on their mechanism of action, chemical structure, or spectrum of activity. They primarily focus on disrupting bacterial functions or growth processes. Antibiotics that target the bacterial cell wall (such as penicillins and cephalosporins) or cell membrane (like polymyxins), or those that inhibit essential bacterial enzymes (including rifamycins, lipiarmycins, quinolones, and sulfonamides), are typically bactericidal. Conversely, antibiotics that disrupt protein synthesis (such as macrolides, lincosamides, and tetracyclines) are often bacteriostatic, although certain aminoglycosides can also be bactericidal.

Classification further depends on target specificity; "narrow-spectrum" antibiotics specifically affect particular bacteria types like Gram-negative or Gram-positive bacteria, while broad-spectrum antibiotics combat a wide array of bacteria. After four decades without the discovery of new antibacterial compound classes, four novel categories emerged in clinical use from the late 2000s to early 2010s: cyclic lipopeptides (e.g., daptomycin), glycylcyclines (e.g., tigecycline), oxazolidinones (e.g., linezolid), and lipiarmycins (e.g., fidaxomicin).
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: With advances in medicinal chemistry, most modern antibacterials are semisynthetic modifications of various natural compounds. These include, for example, the beta-lactam antibiotics, which include the penicillins (produced by fungi in the genus Penicillium), the cephalosporins, and the carbapenems. Compounds that are still isolated from living organisms are the aminoglycosides, whereas other antibacterials—for example, the sulfonamides, the quinolones, and the oxazolidinones—are produced solely by chemical synthesis. Many antibacterial compounds are relatively small molecules with a molecular weight of less than 2000 atomic mass units.[citation needed]
data.label: human

data.text: Thanks to advancements in medicinal chemistry, most contemporary antibacterials are semisynthetic derivatives of natural substances. Some compounds, like aminoglycosides, continue to be extracted from living organisms, while others, including sulfonamides, quinolones, and oxazolidinones, are entirely synthesized chemically. Many antibacterial agents consist of relatively small molecules with molecular weights below 2000 atomic mass units.

While certain compounds like aminoglycosides are still obtained from living organisms, others, including sulfonamides, quinolones, and oxazolidinones, are entirely chemically synthesized. data.text: Antibiotics revolutionized medicine in the 20th century, and have together with vaccination led to the near eradication of diseases such as tuberculosis in the developed world. Their effectiveness and easy access led to overuse, especially in livestock raising, prompting bacteria to develop resistance. This has led to widespread problems with antimicrobial and antibiotic resistance, so much as to prompt the World Health Organization to classify antimicrobial resistance as a "serious threat [that] is no longer a prediction for the future, it is happening right now in every region of the world and has the potential to affect anyone, of any age, in any country".
data.label: human

data.text: The advent of antibiotics dramatically transformed 20th-century medicine, leading alongside vaccinations to nearly eliminate diseases like tuberculosis in developed nations. However, their widespread effectiveness and accessibility resulted in excessive use, particularly in animal husbandry, causing bacteria to develop resistance. This has sparked significant challenges with antimicrobial and antibiotic resistance, prompting the World Health Organization to declare it a "serious threat that is no longer just predicted for the future; it is currently unfolding across all regions of the world, potentially impacting individuals of any age or nationality."
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: The introduction of antibiotics significantly reshaped 20th-century medicine, with vaccines helping to nearly eradicate diseases such as tuberculosis in developed countries. However, their broad effectiveness and accessibility have led to overuse, especially in animal farming, resulting in bacterial resistance development. data.text: In empirical therapy, a patient has proven or suspected infection, but the responsible microorganism is not yet unidentified. While the microorgainsim is being identified the doctor will usually administer the best choice of antibiotic that will be most active against the likely cause of infection usually a broad spectrum antibiotic. Empirical therapy is usually initiated before the doctor knows the exact identification of microorgansim causing the infection as the identification process make take several days in the laboratory.

data.text: In empirical therapy, a patient with a confirmed or suspected infection has an unidentified causative microorganism. While awaiting identification, the physician typically prescribes a broad-spectrum antibiotic expected to be effective against the probable pathogen. Empirical treatment is often started prior to obtaining precise lab results, as microbial identification can take several days.

data.text: In empirical therapy, when a patient has either a confirmed or suspected infection but an unknown causative microorganism, the physician usually prescribes a broad-spectrum antibiotic anticipated to combat the likely pathogen. This approach is initiated before receiving exact lab results because identifying the microbe can take several days.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: Antibiotics are screened for any negative effects on humans or other mammals before approval for clinical use, and are usually considered safe and most are well tolerated. However, some antibiotics have been associated with a range of adverse side effects. Side-effects range from mild to very serious depending on the antibiotics used, the microbial organisms targeted, and the individual patient. Side effects may reflect the pharmacological or toxicological properties of the antibiotic or may involve hypersensitivity reactions or anaphylaxis. Safety profiles of newer drugs are often not as well established as for those that have a long history of use. Adverse effects range from fever and nausea to major allergic reactions, including photodermatitis and anaphylaxis. Common side-effects include diarrhea, resulting from disruption of the species composition in the intestinal flora, resulting, for example, in overgrowth of pathogenic bacteria, such as Clostridium difficile. Antibacterials can also affect the vaginal flora, and may lead to overgrowth of yeast species of the genus Candida in the vulvo-vaginal area. Additional side-effects can result from interaction with other drugs, such as elevated risk of tendon damage from administration of a quinolone antibiotic with a systemic corticosteroid. Some scientists have hypothesized that the indiscriminate use of antibiotics alter the host microbiota and this has been associated with chronic disease.
data.label: human

data.text: Before being approved for clinical application, antibiotics undergo rigorous screening to identify potential negative impacts on humans or other mammals, and they are generally regarded as safe with most being well-tolerated. However, certain antibiotics have been linked to a spectrum of adverse side effects that vary from mild to severe, depending on the specific antibiotic, the targeted microbial organisms, and individual patient factors. These side effects may arise from the pharmacological or toxicological characteristics of the antibiotic or result from hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis. The safety profiles of newer drugs are often less established compared to those with a long history of use. Adverse effects can range from fever and nausea to significant allergic responses such as photodermatitis and anaphylaxis. Diarrhea is a common side effect due to disruption in the intestinal flora, potentially leading to overgrowth of harmful bacteria like Clostridium difficile. Antibacterials may also impact the vaginal flora, causing yeast overgrowth by Candida species in the vulvo-vaginal area. Additional side effects can occur from drug interactions, such as an increased risk of tendon damage when a quinolone antibiotic is used with systemic corticosteroids. Some researchers propose that indiscriminate use of antibiotics may alter host microbiota and contribute to chronic diseases.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: Before clinical approval, antibiotics undergo extensive testing to identify possible adverse effects on humans or other mammals, generally considered safe and well-tolerated. data.text: Exposure to antibiotics early in life is associated with increased body mass in humans and mouse models. Early life is a critical period for the establishment of the intestinal microbiota and for metabolic development. Mice exposed to subtherapeutic antibiotic treatment (STAT)– with either penicillin, vancomycin, penicillin and vancomycin, or chlortetracycline had altered composition of the gut microbiota as well as its metabolic capabilities. Moreover, research have shown that mice given low-dose penicillin (1 μg/g body weight) around birth and throughout the weaning process had an increased body mass and fat mass, accelerated growth, and increased hepatic expression of genes involved in adipogenesis, compared to controlled mice. In addition, penicillin in combination with a high-fat diet increased fasting insulin levels in mice. However, it is unclear whether or not antibiotics cause obesity in humans. Studies have found a correlation between early exposure of antibiotics (<6 months) and increased body mass (at 10 and 20 months). Another study found that the type of antibiotic exposure was also significant with the highest risk of being overweight in those given macrolides compared to penicillin and cephalosporin. Therefore, there is correlation between antibiotic exposure in early life and obesity in humans, but whether or not there is a causal relationship remains unclear. Although there is a correlation between antibiotic use in early life and obesity, the effect of antibiotics on obesity in humans needs to be weighed against the beneficial effects of clinically indicated treatment with antibiotics in infancy.
data.label: human

data.text: Exposure to antibiotics during early life has been linked to increased body mass in both humans and mouse models. This period is crucial for establishing intestinal microbiota and metabolic development. In mice, subtherapeutic antibiotic treatment (STAT) using penicillin, vancomycin, a combination of penicillin and vancomycin, or chlortetracycline resulted in changes to the gut microbiota's composition and its metabolic functions. Research indicates that mice administered low-dose penicillin (1 μg/g body weight) at birth and throughout weaning showed increased body mass, fat accumulation, accelerated growth, and heightened hepatic gene expression related to adipogenesis compared to controls. Additionally, combining penicillin with a high-fat diet elevated fasting insulin levels in mice. However, the causative link between antibiotics and obesity in humans is not well established. Studies have observed a correlation between antibiotic exposure before six months of age and increased body mass at 10 and 20 months. Other research highlights that macrolide exposure carries a higher risk of overweight compared to penicillin or cephalosporin. While there is an association between early-life antibiotic exposure and later obesity in humans, a direct causal relationship remains uncertain. Despite the correlation between early antibiotic use and obesity, it's important to balance this against the benefits of clinically necessary antibiotic treatments during infancy.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: Exposure to antibiotics during early life has been associated with increased body mass in both humans and mice. This critical period is essential for establishing intestinal microbiota and metabolic development. In mouse models, subtherapeutic antibiotic treatment (STAT) using penicillin, vancomycin, a combination of these two antibiotics, or chlortetracycline led to alterations in the gut microbiota's composition and its metabolic functions. Studies show that mice given low-dose penicillin (1 μg/g body weight) from birth through weaning exhibited greater body mass, increased fat accumulation, faster growth rates, and elevated hepatic gene expression related to adipogenesis compared to controls. Furthermore, when combined with a high-fat diet, penicillin resulted in higher fasting insulin levels in mice. However, the causal relationship between antibiotics and obesity in humans remains unclear. Research has identified a link between antibiotic exposure before six months of age and increased body mass at 10 and 20 months. Other studies suggest that macrolide exposure poses a greater risk for overweight conditions compared to penicillin or cephalosporin. Although there is an association between early-life antibiotic exposure and later obesity in humans, the direct causal link is yet to be determined. While a correlation exists between early antibiotic use and subsequent obesity, it is crucial to weigh this against the benefits of clinically necessary antibiotic treatments during infancy.

data.text: The majority of studies indicate antibiotics do interfere with contraceptive pills, such as clinical studies that suggest the failure rate of contraceptive pills caused by antibiotics is very low (about 1%). In cases where antibacterials have been suggested to affect the efficiency of birth control pills, such as for the broad-spectrum antibacterial rifampicin, these cases may be due to an increase in the activities of hepatic liver enzymes' causing increased breakdown of the pill's active ingredients. Effects on the intestinal flora, which might result in reduced absorption of estrogens in the colon, have also been suggested, but such suggestions have been inconclusive and controversial. Clinicians have recommended that extra contraceptive measures be applied during therapies using antibacterials that are suspected to interact with oral contraceptives.
data.label: human

data.text: Most studies suggest antibiotics may impact the effectiveness of contraceptive pills, although clinical evidence indicates a very low failure rate of about 1%. In instances where antibacterial drugs like broad-spectrum rifampicin have been reported to affect birth control pill efficiency, it is often attributed to increased hepatic enzyme activity leading to faster breakdown of active ingredients in the pills. Additionally, there are theories regarding effects on intestinal flora potentially reducing estrogen absorption in the colon; however, these claims remain inconclusive and contentious. Clinicians advise using additional contraceptive measures during treatments with antibacterials suspected of interacting with oral contraceptives.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: Numerous studies indicate that antibiotics might reduce the efficacy of birth control pills, though clinical data shows a minimal failure rate around 1%. When broad-spectrum antibiotics such as rifampicin are reported to decrease contraceptive effectiveness, it is typically linked to heightened hepatic enzyme activity, which accelerates the breakdown of active pill ingredients. There are also hypotheses about the impact on intestinal flora potentially diminishing estrogen absorption in the colon; however, these claims remain unverified and debatable. Therefore, healthcare professionals recommend employing supplementary contraceptive methods during treatments involving antibiotics suspected of interacting with oral contraceptives.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: Interactions between alcohol and certain antibiotics may occur and may cause side-effects and decreased effectiveness of antibiotic therapy. While moderate alcohol consumption is unlikely to interfere with many common antibiotics, there are specific types of antibiotics with which alcohol consumption may cause serious side-effects. Therefore, potential risks of side-effects and effectiveness depend on the type of antibiotic administered. Despite the lack of a categorical counterindication, the belief that alcohol and antibiotics should never be mixed is widespread.
data.label: human

Despite no absolute prohibition against combining them, the belief that alcohol should never be mixed with antibiotics is prevalent.

data.text: Several molecular mechanisms of antibacterial resistance exist. Intrinsic antibacterial resistance may be part of the genetic makeup of bacterial strains. For example, an antibiotic target may be absent from the bacterial genome. Acquired resistance results from a mutation in the bacterial chromosome or the acquisition of extra-chromosomal DNA. Antibacterial-producing bacteria have evolved resistance mechanisms that have been shown to be similar to, and may have been transferred to, antibacterial-resistant strains. The spread of antibacterial resistance often occurs through vertical transmission of mutations during growth and by genetic recombination of DNA by horizontal genetic exchange. For instance, antibacterial resistance genes can be exchanged between different bacterial strains or species via plasmids that carry these resistance genes. Plasmids that carry several different resistance genes can confer resistance to multiple antibacterials. Cross-resistance to several antibacterials may also occur when a resistance mechanism encoded by a single gene conveys resistance to more than one antibacterial compound.
data.label: human

data.text: Multiple molecular mechanisms underlie antibacterial resistance. Intrinsic resistance is often inherent in the genetic composition of specific bacterial strains, such as when an antibiotic target is missing from their genome. Acquired resistance arises from mutations within the bacterial chromosome or through obtaining extra-chromosomal DNA. Bacteria that produce antibiotics have developed resistance strategies similar to those found in resistant strains and may transfer these mechanisms between them. The dissemination of antibacterial resistance typically happens via vertical transmission of genetic mutations during reproduction and horizontal gene transfer through recombination processes. For example, plasmids can facilitate the exchange of resistance genes among various bacterial strains or species. Plasmids carrying multiple resistance genes can enable bacteria to resist several antibiotics simultaneously. Additionally, cross-resistance occurs when a single gene imparts resistance to multiple antibacterial agents.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: Antibacterial resistance is driven by numerous molecular mechanisms. Intrinsic resistance often stems from the genetic makeup of specific bacterial strains, such as when they lack an antibiotic target in their genome. Acquired resistance develops through mutations within the bacterial chromosome or via extra-chromosomal DNA acquisition. Bacteria that synthesize antibiotics have evolved similar resistance strategies to those found in resistant strains and can transfer these mechanisms among them. The spread of antibacterial resistance typically occurs through vertical transmission of genetic mutations during reproduction and horizontal gene transfer via recombination processes. For instance, plasmids enable the exchange of resistance genes across different bacterial strains or species. Plasmids that carry multiple resistance genes allow bacteria to withstand several antibiotics concurrently. Furthermore, cross-resistance arises when a single gene confers resistance to various antibacterial agents.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: Antibacterial-resistant strains and species, sometimes referred to as "superbugs", now contribute to the emergence of diseases that were for a while well controlled. For example, emergent bacterial strains causing tuberculosis (TB) that are resistant to previously effective antibacterial treatments pose many therapeutic challenges. Every year, nearly half a million new cases of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) are estimated to occur worldwide. For example, NDM-1 is a newly identified enzyme conveying bacterial resistance to a broad range of beta-lactam antibacterials. The United Kingdom's Health Protection Agency has stated that "most isolates with NDM-1 enzyme are resistant to all standard intravenous antibiotics for treatment of severe infections."
data.label: human

data.text: Antibacterial-resistant strains, often called "superbugs," contribute to the resurgence of diseases previously well-managed. For instance, newly emerging bacterial strains causing tuberculosis (TB) that resist formerly effective treatments present significant therapeutic challenges. It is estimated that nearly half a million new cases of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) occur globally each year. An example is NDM-1, an enzyme recently identified for its role in conferring bacterial resistance to a wide array of beta-lactam antibacterials. The United Kingdom's Health Protection Agency has reported that "most isolates with the NDM-1 enzyme are resistant to all standard intravenous antibiotics used for treating severe infections."

data.text: Bacterial strains resistant to antibiotics, commonly referred to as "superbugs," have contributed to a resurgence of diseases previously under control. data.text: Inappropriate antibiotic treatment and overuse of antibiotics have contributed to the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Self prescription of antibiotics is an example of misuse. Many antibiotics are frequently prescribed to treat symptoms or diseases that do not respond to antibiotics or that are likely to resolve without treatment. Also, incorrect or suboptimal antibiotics are prescribed for certain bacterial infections. The overuse of antibiotics, like penicillin and erythromycin, has been associated with emerging antibiotic resistance since the 1950s. Widespread usage of antibiotics in hospitals has also been associated with increases in bacterial strains and species that no longer respond to treatment with the most common antibiotics.
data.label: human

data.text: The inappropriate use and overuse of antibiotics have fueled the rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Self-prescription is a typical instance of misuse. Antibiotics are often prescribed for conditions or symptoms unresponsive to them, or those likely to resolve naturally. Additionally, improper or suboptimal antibiotics may be chosen for specific bacterial infections. Since the 1950s, overusing antibiotics like penicillin and erythromycin has led to increased resistance. Hospital use of antibiotics has also contributed to a rise in bacterial strains resistant to common treatments.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text: The misuse and excessive use of antibiotics have driven the increase of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. A common example of misuse is self-prescription. Antibiotics are frequently prescribed for ailments or symptoms that do not respond to them, or those expected to resolve on their own. Furthermore, inappropriate or suboptimal antibiotics may be selected for certain bacterial infections. Since the 1950s, overuse of antibiotics such as penicillin and erythromycin has heightened resistance levels. The use of antibiotics in hospitals has also led to a surge in bacteria resistant to standard treatments.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: Common forms of antibiotic misuse include excessive use of prophylactic antibiotics in travelers and failure of medical professionals to prescribe the correct dosage of antibiotics on the basis of the patient's weight and history of prior use. Other forms of misuse include failure to take the entire prescribed course of the antibiotic, incorrect dosage and administration, or failure to rest for sufficient recovery. Inappropriate antibiotic treatment, for example, is their prescription to treat viral infections such as the common cold. One study on respiratory tract infections found "physicians were more likely to prescribe antibiotics to patients who appeared to expect them". Multifactorial interventions aimed at both physicians and patients can reduce inappropriate prescription of antibiotics.
data.label: human

data.text: Widespread forms of antibiotic misuse involve the overuse of prophylactic antibiotics by travelers and medical professionals not prescribing dosages based on a patient's weight or history of prior use. Misuse also includes patients not completing their prescribed antibiotic course, taking incorrect dosages, improper administration, or inadequate rest for recovery. Inappropriate treatment includes using antibiotics to combat viral infections like the common cold. Research on respiratory tract infections revealed that physicians often prescribe antibiotics when patients seem to anticipate receiving them. Interventions targeting both physicians and patients can help decrease the inappropriate prescription of antibiotics.

data.text: Antibiotic misuse is commonly seen in the excessive use of prophylactic antibiotics by travelers and healthcare professionals who do not tailor dosages according to a patient's weight or history of previous antibiotic use. Misuse also encompasses scenarios where patients fail to finish their prescribed course, take incorrect doses, improperly administer them, or lack sufficient rest for recovery. Antibiotics are inappropriately used to treat viral infections such as the common cold. data.text: Several organizations concerned with antimicrobial resistance are lobbying to eliminate the unnecessary use of antibiotics. The issues of misuse and overuse of antibiotics have been addressed by the formation of the US Interagency Task Force on Antimicrobial Resistance. This task force aims to actively address antimicrobial resistance, and is coordinated by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH), as well as other US agencies. An NGO campaign group is Keep Antibiotics Working. In France, an "Antibiotics are not automatic" government campaign started in 2002 and led to a marked reduction of unnecessary antibiotic prescriptions, especially in children.

data.text: The emergence of antibiotic resistance has prompted restrictions on their use in the UK in 1970 (Swann report 1969), and the EU has banned the use of antibiotics as growth-promotional agents since 2003. Moreover, several organizations (e.g., The American Society for Microbiology (ASM), American Public Health Association (APHA) and the American Medical Association (AMA)) have called for restrictions on antibiotic use in food animal production and an end to all nontherapeutic uses.[citation needed] However, commonly there are delays in regulatory and legislative actions to limit the use of antibiotics, attributable partly to resistance against such regulation by industries using or selling antibiotics, and to the time required for research to test causal links between their use and resistance to them. Two federal bills (S.742 and H.R. 2562) aimed at phasing out nontherapeutic use of antibiotics in US food animals were proposed, but have not passed. These bills were endorsed by public health and medical organizations, including the American Holistic Nurses' Association, the American Medical Association, and the American Public Health Association (APHA).
data.label: human

data.text: The rise of antibiotic resistance led to restrictions on their use in the UK following the 1969 Swann report, and since 2003, the EU has prohibited antibiotics as growth-promoting agents. Additionally, organizations such as The American Society for Microbiology (ASM), the American Public Health Association (APHA), and the American Medical Association (AMA) have advocated for limiting antibiotic use in animal food production and discontinuing all nontherapeutic applications.[citation needed] Nonetheless, regulatory and legislative measures to curtail antibiotic usage often experience delays due to industry resistance and the time required for research to establish causal connections between their use and resultant resistance. Although two federal bills, S.742 and H.R. 2562, aimed at ending nontherapeutic antibiotic use in U.S. food animals were introduced, they have not been enacted. These proposals received support from public health and medical organizations, including the American Holistic Nurses' Association, the American Medical Association, and the American Public Health Association (APHA).

data.text: There has been extensive use of antibiotics in animal husbandry. In the United States, the question of emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains due to use of antibiotics in livestock was raised by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 1977. In March 2012, the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, ruling in an action brought by the Natural Resources Defense Council and others, ordered the FDA to revoke approvals for the use of antibiotics in livestock, which violated FDA regulations.

data.text: Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections were described over 2000 years ago. Many ancient cultures, including the ancient Egyptians and ancient Greeks, used specially selected mold and plant materials and extracts to treat infections. More recent observations made in the laboratory of antibiosis between microorganisms led to the discovery of natural antibacterials produced by microorganisms. Louis Pasteur observed, "if we could intervene in the antagonism observed between some bacteria, it would offer perhaps the greatest hopes for therapeutics". The term 'antibiosis', meaning "against life", was introduced by the French bacteriologist Jean Paul Vuillemin as a descriptive name of the phenomenon exhibited by these early antibacterial drugs. Antibiosis was first described in 1877 in bacteria when Louis Pasteur and Robert Koch observed that an airborne bacillus could inhibit the growth of Bacillus anthracis. These drugs were later renamed antibiotics by Selman Waksman, an American microbiologist, in 1942. Synthetic antibiotic chemotherapy as a science and development of antibacterials began in Germany with Paul Ehrlich in the late 1880s. Ehrlich noted certain dyes would color human, animal, or bacterial cells, whereas others did not. He then proposed the idea that it might be possible to create chemicals that would act as a selective drug that would bind to and kill bacteria without harming the human host. After screening hundreds of dyes against various organisms, in 1907, he discovered a medicinally useful drug, the synthetic antibacterial salvarsan now called arsphenamine.
data.label: human

data.text:
Prior to the early 20th century, infection treatments relied heavily on medicinal folklore. Over two millennia ago, mixtures with antimicrobial properties were documented for treating infections. Cultures like the ancient Egyptians and Greeks utilized selected molds and plant extracts for this purpose. Laboratory observations of antibiosis between microorganisms led to identifying natural antibacterials produced by microbes. Louis Pasteur suggested that manipulating bacterial antagonism could significantly advance therapeutics. The term 'antibiosis,' meaning "against life," was coined by French bacteriologist Jean Paul Vuillemin to describe the effect of early antibacterial drugs. This phenomenon, first described in 1877 when Louis Pasteur and Robert Koch observed an airborne bacillus inhibiting Bacillus anthracis growth, later became known as antibiotics after being renamed by American microbiologist Selman Waksman in 1942.

The development of synthetic antibiotic chemotherapy began in Germany with Paul Ehrlich in the late 1880s. He discovered that certain dyes could selectively color cells without affecting others and hypothesized creating selective drugs to target bacteria while sparing humans. Through extensive screening, he identified salvarsan, now known as arsphenamine, a medically beneficial synthetic antibacterial drug, in 1907.

data.text:
Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections primarily depended on traditional medicinal practices. Over two thousand years ago, mixtures with antimicrobial properties were recorded for combating infections. Ancient civilizations such as the Egyptians and Greeks employed specific molds and plant extracts for these purposes. Observations in laboratories of antibiosis among microorganisms led to identifying natural antibacterials produced by microbes. Louis Pasteur proposed that leveraging bacterial antagonism could greatly enhance therapeutic methods. The term "antibiosis," meaning "against life," was introduced by French bacteriologist Jean Paul Vuillemin to describe the effect of early antibacterial drugs. This phenomenon, first noted in 1877 when Louis Pasteur and Robert Koch discovered an airborne bacillus inhibiting Bacillus anthracis growth, was later termed antibiotics after American microbiologist Selman Waksman renamed it in 1942.

The development of synthetic antibiotic chemotherapy began in Germany with Paul Ehrlich in the late 1880s. He found that certain dyes could selectively stain cells without harming others and hypothesized developing drugs to target bacteria while sparing humans. After extensive testing, he identified salvarsan, now known as arsphenamine, a beneficial synthetic antibacterial drug, in 1907.

data.text: The effects of some types of mold on infection had been noticed many times over the course of history (see: History of penicillin). In 1928, Alexander Fleming noticed the same effect in a Petri dish, where a number of disease-causing bacteria were killed by a fungus of the genus Penicillium. Fleming postulated that the effect is mediated by an antibacterial compound he named penicillin, and that its antibacterial properties could be exploited for chemotherapy. He initially characterized some of its biological properties, and attempted to use a crude preparation to treat some infections, but he was unable to pursue its further development without the aid of trained chemists.

data.text: The first sulfonamide and first commercially available antibacterial, Prontosil, was developed by a research team led by Gerhard Domagk in 1932 at the Bayer Laboratories of the IG Farben conglomerate in Germany. Domagk received the 1939 Nobel Prize for Medicine for his efforts. Prontosil had a relatively broad effect against Gram-positive cocci, but not against enterobacteria. Research was stimulated apace by its success. The discovery and development of this sulfonamide drug opened the era of antibacterials.

data.text: In 1939, coinciding with the start of World War II, Rene Dubos reported the discovery of the first naturally derived antibiotic, tyrothricin, a compound of 20% gramicidin and 80% tyrocidine, from B. brevis. It was one of the first commercially manufactured antibiotics universally and was very effective in treating wounds and ulcers during World War II. Gramicidin, however, could not be used systemically because of toxicity. Tyrocidine also proved too toxic for systemic usage. Research results obtained during that period were not shared between the Axis and the Allied powers during the war.
data.label: human

It became one of the initial antibiotics to be widely manufactured and commercially distributed, proving highly effective in treating wounds and ulcers during the war. Despite its effectiveness, gramicidin could not be used systemically due to its toxicity, and similarly, tyrocidine was too toxic for systemic application. This marked one of the earliest antibiotics to be mass-produced and widely distributed commercially, demonstrating significant efficacy in treating wounds and ulcers during the conflict. data.text: Florey and Chain succeeded in purifying the first penicillin, penicillin G, in 1942, but it did not become widely available outside the Allied military before 1945. Later, Norman Heatley developed the back extraction technique for efficiently purifying penicillin in bulk. The chemical structure of penicillin was determined by Dorothy Crowfoot Hodgkin in 1945. Purified penicillin displayed potent antibacterial activity against a wide range of bacteria and had low toxicity in humans. Furthermore, its activity was not inhibited by biological constituents such as pus, unlike the synthetic sulfonamides. The discovery of such a powerful antibiotic was unprecedented, and the development of penicillin led to renewed interest in the search for antibiotic compounds with similar efficacy and safety. For their successful development of penicillin, which Fleming had accidentally discovered but could not develop himself, as a therapeutic drug, Ernst Chain and Howard Florey shared the 1945 Nobel Prize in Medicine with Fleming. Florey credited Dubos with pioneering the approach of deliberately and systematically searching for antibacterial compounds, which had led to the discovery of gramicidin and had revived Florey's research in penicillin.
data.label: human

data.text: In 1942, Florey and Chain successfully purified the first form of penicillin, known as penicillin G; however, it wasn't widely accessible outside the Allied military until 1945. Later, Norman Heatley innovated a back extraction technique for efficiently purifying penicillin in large quantities. The chemical structure was determined by Dorothy Crowfoot Hodgkin in 1945. This purified form of penicillin exhibited strong antibacterial effects across various bacteria while maintaining low toxicity to humans. Additionally, its effectiveness wasn't diminished by biological substances like pus, unlike synthetic sulfonamides. The discovery of such a potent antibiotic was unprecedented and spurred renewed interest in finding other antibiotics with similar efficacy and safety. For their pivotal role in developing penicillin as a therapeutic drug—a breakthrough Fleming had initially discovered but couldn’t develop—Ernst Chain and Howard Florey were awarded the 1945 Nobel Prize in Medicine alongside Fleming. Florey acknowledged Dubos's pioneering efforts in systematically searching for antibacterial compounds, which led to the discovery of gramicidin and revitalized Florey’s penicillin research.

data.text: Vaccines rely on immune modulation or augmentation. Vaccination either excites or reinforces the immune competence of a host to ward off infection, leading to the activation of macrophages, the production of antibodies, inflammation, and other classic immune reactions. Antibacterial vaccines have been responsible for a drastic reduction in global bacterial diseases. Vaccines made from attenuated whole cells or lysates have been replaced largely by less reactogenic, cell-free vaccines consisting of purified components, including capsular polysaccharides and their conjugates, to protein carriers, as well as inactivated toxins (toxoids) and proteins.

data.text: Phage therapy is another option that is being looked into for treating resistant strains of bacteria. The way that researchers are doing this is by infecting pathogenic bacteria with their own viruses, more specifically, bacteriophages. Bacteriophages, also known simply as phages, are precisely bacterial viruses that infect bacteria by disrupting pathogenic bacterium lytic cycles. By disrupting the lytic cycles of bacterium, phages destroy their metabolism, which eventually results in the cell's death. Phages will insert their DNA into the bacterium, allowing their DNA to be transcribed. Once their DNA is transcribed the cell will proceed to make new phages and as soon as they are ready to be released, the cell will lyse. One of the worries about using phages to fight pathogens is that the phages will infect "good" bacteria, or the bacteria that are important in the everyday function of human beings. However, studies have proven that phages are very specific when they target bacteria, which makes researchers confident that bacteriophage therapy is the definite route to defeating antibiotic resistant bacteria.
data.label: human

data.text:
Phage therapy is being explored as an alternative for combating antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains. Researchers achieve this by using bacteriophages—viruses specifically targeting bacteria—to infect harmful bacteria. These phages disrupt the lytic cycles of pathogenic bacteria, impairing their metabolism and leading to cell death. Upon infection, phages insert their DNA into the host bacterium, allowing transcription and subsequent production of new phages. Once matured, these phages cause the bacterial cell to lyse and release them.

A concern with phage therapy is its potential impact on beneficial bacteria crucial for human health. However, studies have shown that phages exhibit high specificity in targeting bacteria, bolstering confidence among researchers that phage therapy could effectively address antibiotic-resistant infections.
data.label: qwen_1

data.text:
Phage therapy is being investigated as a potential alternative to combat antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains. Researchers employ bacteriophages—viruses that specifically target bacteria—to infect and attack harmful bacteria. These phages interfere with the lytic cycles of pathogenic bacteria, disrupting their metabolism and resulting in cell death. Upon infection, the phages integrate their DNA into the host bacterium, facilitating transcription and the production of new phages. Once matured, these phages cause the bacterial cell to rupture, releasing them.

A concern regarding phage therapy is its possible effect on beneficial bacteria that are vital for human health. However, studies indicate that phages have a high specificity in targeting bacteria, increasing researchers' confidence that phage therapy could effectively tackle antibiotic-resistant infections.

data.text: Possible improvements include clarification of clinical trial regulations by FDA. Furthermore, appropriate economic incentives could persuade pharmaceutical companies to invest in this endeavor. Antibiotic Development to Advance Patient Treatment (ADAPT) Act aims to fast track the drug development to combat the growing threat of 'superbugs'. Under this Act, FDA can approve antibiotics and antifungals treating life-threatening infections based on smaller clinical trials. The CDC will monitor the use of antibiotics and the emerging resistance, and publish the data. The FDA antibiotics labeling process, 'Susceptibility Test Interpretive Criteria for Microbial Organisms' or 'breakpoints', will provide accurate data to healthcare professionals. According to Allan Coukell, senior director for health programs at The Pew Charitable Trusts, "By allowing drug developers to rely on smaller datasets, and clarifying FDA's authority to tolerate a higher level of uncertainty for these drugs when making a risk/benefit calculation, ADAPT would make the clinical trials more feasible."
data.label: human

data.text: Frédéric François Chopin (/ˈʃoʊpæn/; French pronunciation: ​[fʁe.de.ʁik fʁɑ̃.swa ʃɔ.pɛ̃]; 22 February or 1 March 1810 – 17 October 1849), born Fryderyk Franciszek Chopin,[n 1] was a Polish and French (by citizenship and birth of father) composer and a virtuoso pianist of the Romantic era, who wrote primarily for the solo piano. He gained and has maintained renown worldwide as one of the leading musicians of his era, whose "poetic genius was based on a professional technique that was without equal in his generation." Chopin was born in what was then the Duchy of Warsaw, and grew up in Warsaw, which after 1815 became part of Congress Poland. A child prodigy, he completed his musical education and composed his earlier works in Warsaw before leaving Poland at the age of 20, less than a month before the outbreak of the November 1830 Uprising.
data.label: human

data.text: Frédéric François Chopin (/ˈʃoʊpæn/; French pronunciation: [fʁe.de.ʁik fʁɑ̃.swa ʃɔ.pɛ̃]; born on February 22 or March 1, 1810 – died October 17, 1849), originally named Fryderyk Franciszek Chopin, was a distinguished composer and virtuoso pianist of Polish and French heritage (by citizenship through his father). Primarily composing for solo piano during the Romantic era, he achieved and continues to hold worldwide acclaim as one of the most eminent musicians of his time. His "poetic genius," built on an unmatched professional technique in his generation, is well-recognized. Born in the Duchy of Warsaw (now part of Congress Poland after 1815), Chopin was raised in Warsaw. Demonstrating prodigious talent from a young age, he completed his musical studies and composed early works there before departing Poland at age 20, shortly before the November 1830 Uprising commenced.

data.text: Frédéric François Chopin (pronounced /ˈʃoʊpæn/; French pronunciation: [fʁe.de.ʁik fʁɑ̃.swa ʃɔ.pɛ̃]; born on February 22 or March 1, 1810 – died October 17, 1849), originally Fryderyk Franciszek Chopin, was a renowned composer and pianist of Polish and French descent (through his father's citizenship). A prolific solo piano composer of the Romantic era, he is celebrated globally as one of the most distinguished musicians of his time. His "poetic genius," rooted in an unparalleled professional technique among his contemporaries, is well acknowledged. Born in the Duchy of Warsaw (which became part of Congress Poland after 1815), Chopin was raised there and displayed exceptional musical talent from a young age. He completed his studies and composed early works in Warsaw before leaving Poland at 20, shortly before the November 1830 Uprising began.

data.text: At the age of 21 he settled in Paris. Thereafter, during the last 18 years of his life, he gave only some 30 public performances, preferring the more intimate atmosphere of the salon. He supported himself by selling his compositions and teaching piano, for which he was in high demand. Chopin formed a friendship with Franz Liszt and was admired by many of his musical contemporaries, including Robert Schumann. In 1835 he obtained French citizenship. After a failed engagement to Maria Wodzińska, from 1837 to 1847 he maintained an often troubled relationship with the French writer George Sand. A brief and unhappy visit to Majorca with Sand in 1838–39 was one of his most productive periods of composition. In his last years, he was financially supported by his admirer Jane Stirling, who also arranged for him to visit Scotland in 1848. Through most of his life, Chopin suffered from poor health. He died in Paris in 1849, probably of tuberculosis.
data.label: human

data.text: At the age of 21, he relocated to Paris, where over the next 18 years of his life, he chose to perform publicly only about 30 times, favoring the more personal setting of salons. To support himself, he sold his compositions and taught piano—a skill for which he was highly sought after. He developed a friendship with Franz Liszt and earned admiration from several musical peers, including Robert Schumann. In 1835, he became a French citizen. Following an unsuccessful engagement to Maria Wodzińska, he entered into a tumultuous relationship with the writer George Sand between 1837 and 1847. One of his most fruitful periods of composition occurred during a challenging visit to Majorca with Sand in 1838–39. In his later years, Jane Stirling, an admirer who financially supported him, also organized a trip for him to Scotland in 1848. Throughout much of his life, he battled chronic ill health and ultimately passed away in Paris in 1849, likely due to tuberculosis.

data.text: At 21, he moved to Paris, where over the subsequent 18 years, he performed publicly only around 30 times, preferring intimate salons. To sustain himself, he sold his compositions and taught piano—a skill for which demand was high. He formed a friendship with Franz Liszt and gained admiration from musical peers like Robert Schumann. In 1835, he became a French citizen. After an unsuccessful engagement to Maria Wodzińska, he entered into a turbulent relationship with writer George Sand between 1837 and 1847. A productive period of composition occurred during a challenging stay on Majorca with Sand in 1838–39. Later, Jane Stirling, who financially supported him, arranged a trip for him to Scotland in 1848. Throughout much of his life, he suffered from chronic ill health and passed away in Paris in 1849, likely due to tuberculosis.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: All of Chopin's compositions include the piano. Most are for solo piano, though he also wrote two piano concertos, a few chamber pieces, and some songs to Polish lyrics. His keyboard style is highly individual and often technically demanding; his own performances were noted for their nuance and sensitivity. Chopin invented the concept of instrumental ballade. His major piano works also include mazurkas, waltzes, nocturnes, polonaises, études, impromptus, scherzos, preludes and sonatas, some published only after his death. Influences on his compositional style include Polish folk music, the classical tradition of J. S. Bach, Mozart and Schubert, the music of all of whom he admired, as well as the Paris salons where he was a frequent guest. His innovations in style, musical form, and harmony, and his association of music with nationalism, were influential throughout and after the late Romantic period.

data.text: Chopin composed exclusively for the piano, with most pieces intended for solo performance. He also penned two concertos for piano, a number of chamber works, and several songs set to Polish texts. His distinctive keyboard technique is known for its complexity; his personal performances were celebrated for their subtle expressiveness and delicate touch. Chopin pioneered the concept of the instrumental ballade. His significant piano compositions encompass mazurkas, waltzes, nocturnes, polonaises, études, impromptus, scherzos, preludes, and sonatas, with some released posthumously. Polish folk music, along with the classical traditions of J.S. Bach, Mozart, and Schubert—all of whom he esteemed—shaped his style, as did the Parisian salons where he was a regular attendee. His groundbreaking contributions to musical style, form, and harmony, coupled with his linking of music and nationalism, left a lasting impact during and beyond the late Romantic era.

His works remain popular, and he has been the subject of numerous films and biographies of varying degrees of historical accuracy.

data.text: Fryderyk Chopin was born in Żelazowa Wola, 46 kilometres (29 miles) west of Warsaw, in what was then the Duchy of Warsaw, a Polish state established by Napoleon. The parish baptismal record gives his birthday as 22 February 1810, and cites his given names in the Latin form Fridericus Franciscus (in Polish, he was Fryderyk Franciszek). However, the composer and his family used the birthdate 1 March,[n 2] which is now generally accepted as the correct date.

data.text: Fryderyk's father, Nicolas Chopin, was a Frenchman from Lorraine who had emigrated to Poland in 1787 at the age of sixteen. Nicolas tutored children of the Polish aristocracy, and in 1806 married Justyna Krzyżanowska, a poor relative of the Skarbeks, one of the families for whom he worked. Fryderyk was baptized on Easter Sunday, 23 April 1810, in the same church where his parents had married, in Brochów. His eighteen-year-old godfather, for whom he was named, was Fryderyk Skarbek, a pupil of Nicolas Chopin. Fryderyk was the couple's second child and only son; he had an elder sister, Ludwika (1807–55), and two younger sisters, Izabela (1811–81) and Emilia (1812–27). Nicolas was devoted to his adopted homeland, and insisted on the use of the Polish language in the household.

data.text: In October 1810, six months after Fryderyk's birth, the family moved to Warsaw, where his father acquired a post teaching French at the Warsaw Lyceum, then housed in the Saxon Palace. Fryderyk lived with his family in the Palace grounds. The father played the flute and violin; the mother played the piano and gave lessons to boys in the boarding house that the Chopins kept. Chopin was of slight build, and even in early childhood was prone to illnesses.

data.text: Fryderyk may have had some piano instruction from his mother, but his first professional music tutor, from 1816 to 1821, was the Czech pianist Wojciech Żywny. His elder sister Ludwika also took lessons from Żywny, and occasionally played duets with her brother. It quickly became apparent that he was a child prodigy. By the age of seven Fryderyk had begun giving public concerts, and in 1817 he composed two polonaises, in G minor and B-flat major. His next work, a polonaise in A-flat major of 1821, dedicated to Żywny, is his earliest surviving musical manuscript.

data.text: In 1817 the Saxon Palace was requisitioned by Warsaw's Russian governor for military use, and the Warsaw Lyceum was reestablished in the Kazimierz Palace (today the rectorate of Warsaw University). Fryderyk and his family moved to a building, which still survives, adjacent to the Kazimierz Palace. During this period, Fryderyk was sometimes invited to the Belweder Palace as playmate to the son of the ruler of Russian Poland, Grand Duke Constantine; he played the piano for the Duke and composed a march for him. Julian Ursyn Niemcewicz, in his dramatic eclogue, "Nasze Przebiegi" ("Our Discourses", 1818), attested to "little Chopin's" popularity.

data.text: From September 1823 to 1826 Chopin attended the Warsaw Lyceum, where he received organ lessons from the Czech musician Wilhelm Würfel during his first year. In the autumn of 1826 he began a three-year course under the Silesian composer Józef Elsner at the Warsaw Conservatory, studying music theory, figured bass and composition.[n 3] Throughout this period he continued to compose and to give recitals in concerts and salons in Warsaw. He was engaged by the inventors of a mechanical organ, the "eolomelodicon", and on this instrument in May 1825 he performed his own improvisation and part of a concerto by Moscheles. The success of this concert led to an invitation to give a similar recital on the instrument before Tsar Alexander I, who was visiting Warsaw; the Tsar presented him with a diamond ring. At a subsequent eolomelodicon concert on 10 June 1825, Chopin performed his Rondo Op. 1. This was the first of his works to be commercially published and earned him his first mention in the foreign press, when the Leipzig Allgemeine Musikalische Zeitung praised his "wealth of musical ideas".
data.label: human

data.text: During 1824–28 Chopin spent his vacations away from Warsaw, at a number of locales.[n 4] In 1824 and 1825, at Szafarnia, he was a guest of Dominik Dziewanowski, the father of a schoolmate. Here for the first time he encountered Polish rural folk music. His letters home from Szafarnia (to which he gave the title "The Szafarnia Courier"), written in a very modern and lively Polish, amused his family with their spoofing of the Warsaw newspapers and demonstrated the youngster's literary gift.

data.text: In 1827, soon after the death of Chopin's youngest sister Emilia, the family moved from the Warsaw University building, adjacent to the Kazimierz Palace, to lodgings just across the street from the university, in the south annex of the Krasiński Palace on Krakowskie Przedmieście,[n 5] where Chopin lived until he left Warsaw in 1830.[n 6] Here his parents continued running their boarding house for male students; the Chopin Family Parlour (Salonik Chopinów) became a museum in the 20th century. In 1829 the artist Ambroży Mieroszewski executed a set of portraits of Chopin family members, including the first known portrait of the composer.[n 7]

data.text: Four boarders at his parents' apartments became Chopin's intimates: Tytus Woyciechowski, Jan Nepomucen Białobłocki, Jan Matuszyński and Julian Fontana; the latter two would become part of his Paris milieu. He was friendly with members of Warsaw's young artistic and intellectual world, including Fontana, Józef Bohdan Zaleski and Stefan Witwicki. He was also attracted to the singing student Konstancja Gładkowska. In letters to Woyciechowski, he indicated which of his works, and even which of their passages, were influenced by his fascination with her; his letter of 15 May 1830 revealed that the slow movement (Larghetto) of his Piano Concerto No. 1 (in E minor) was secretly dedicated to her – "It should be like dreaming in beautiful springtime – by moonlight." His final Conservatory report (July 1829) read: "Chopin F., third-year student, exceptional talent, musical genius."

data.text: In September 1828 Chopin, while still a student, visited Berlin with a family friend, zoologist Feliks Jarocki, enjoying operas directed by Gaspare Spontini and attending concerts by Carl Friedrich Zelter, Felix Mendelssohn and other celebrities. On an 1829 return trip to Berlin, he was a guest of Prince Antoni Radziwiłł, governor of the Grand Duchy of Posen—himself an accomplished composer and aspiring cellist. For the prince and his pianist daughter Wanda, he composed his Introduction and Polonaise brillante in C major for cello and piano, Op. 3.

data.text: Back in Warsaw that year, Chopin heard Niccolò Paganini play the violin, and composed a set of variations, Souvenir de Paganini. It may have been this experience which encouraged him to commence writing his first Études, (1829–32), exploring the capacities of his own instrument. On 11 August, three weeks after completing his studies at the Warsaw Conservatory, he made his debut in Vienna. He gave two piano concerts and received many favourable reviews—in addition to some commenting (in Chopin's own words) that he was "too delicate for those accustomed to the piano-bashing of local artists". In one of these concerts, he premiered his Variations on Là ci darem la mano, Op. 2 (variations on an aria from Mozart's opera Don Giovanni) for piano and orchestra. He returned to Warsaw in September 1829, where he premiered his Piano Concerto No. 2 in F minor, Op. 21 on 17 March 1830.

data.text: Chopin's successes as a composer and performer opened the door to western Europe for him, and on 2 November 1830, he set out, in the words of Zdzisław Jachimecki, "into the wide world, with no very clearly defined aim, forever." With Woyciechowski, he headed for Austria, intending to go on to Italy. Later that month, in Warsaw, the November 1830 Uprising broke out, and Woyciechowski returned to Poland to enlist. Chopin, now alone in Vienna, was nostalgic for his homeland, and wrote to a friend, "I curse the moment of my departure." When in September 1831 he learned, while travelling from Vienna to Paris, that the uprising had been crushed, he expressed his anguish in the pages of his private journal: "Oh God! ... You are there, and yet you do not take vengeance!" Jachimecki ascribes to these events the composer's maturing "into an inspired national bard who intuited the past, present and future of his native Poland."
data.label: human

data.text: Chopin's dual success as a composer and performer established his presence in Western Europe. Traveling alongside Woyciechowski, they initially set off for Austria with intentions to proceed to Italy. However, later that month, the November 1830 Uprising in Warsaw led Woyciechowski to return and join the fight. Left alone in Vienna, Chopin felt a deep sense of nostalgia, confessing to a friend: "I curse the moment of my departure." When he traveled from Vienna to Paris in September 1831 and learned that the uprising had been crushed, his anguish was evident in his private journal: "Oh God! ... You are there, and yet you do not take vengeance!" data.text: Chopin arrived in Paris in late September 1831; he would never return to Poland, thus becoming one of many expatriates of the Polish Great Emigration. In France he used the French versions of his given names, and after receiving French citizenship in 1835, he travelled on a French passport. However, Chopin remained close to his fellow Poles in exile as friends and confidants and he never felt fully comfortable speaking French. Chopin's biographer Adam Zamoyski writes that he never considered himself to be French, despite his father's French origins, and always saw himself as a Pole.
data.label: human

data.text: Fryderyk Chopin arrived in Paris in late September 1831 and would not return to Poland, becoming one of the many expatriates of the Polish Great Emigration. In France, he adopted French versions of his given names and began using a French passport after obtaining citizenship in 1835. Despite this, Chopin maintained strong connections with other Polish exiles as friends and confidants and never felt entirely at ease speaking French. According to his biographer Adam Zamoyski, Chopin did not regard himself as French, regardless of his father's French heritage, always identifying himself as a Pole.
data.label: qwen_1
